title.narrative: Curriculum and Lecturer Development Programme for the Maritime and Energy Sector

description.narrative:
Following the discovery of natural gas in the Rovuma Basin in the northern part of Mozambique, the country of Mozambique is preparing itself for an economic boost. The boost is will have a positive effect on the country in general and on the people more specifically. Industrial development also means that the need for knowledgeable and competent people will grow. In this case de demand for people working in the maritime and energy sector will increase. As a result the position and role of education and training institutes are becoming increasingly important.
This project is aiming at upgrading and further strengthening the people working at Escola Superior de Sciencias Nauticas (ESCN), the recipient of the project. The capacity of the lecturing and teaching staff will be strengthened by: Increasing the didactical skills (IMO model courses 6.09, 6.10 and 3.12); Development of course material for seven (7) courses in the English and Portuguese language; Transferring the knowledge to the staff of ESCN, the Ministry of Transport and Communications, and the maritime and energy sector.
In the light of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, a Gender Policy Study & Workshop will be executed as well.
This project is aiming at contributing to the further development of the people in the country of Mozambique.

The proposed project must contribute to the following ++objective++:
- Contribute to inclusive sustainable development and end poverty in all its forms (SDG 1)
The proposed project must contribute to the following ++long-term impact++:
- Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy; and - Maritime sector operates in accordance with international (security and skills) requirements, creating more jobs and added value in infrastructural (transport) development.
The following ++medium-term impact++ will contribute to this:
(I) Education system (TVET/HE) is of good quality, relevant and accessible (SDG 4);
(II) Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable (SDG 17);
(III) Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce.
This will be achieved by the following ++outcome++:
B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs and aiming at inclusiveness.
To that end, the following ++output(s)++ must be achieved by the end of the project:
1. Develop and implement training for the instructors and lecturers 2. Develop curriculum and execution of training courses 3. Project result dissemination and sustainability

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands
P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.8. Number of staff of Dutch training education organisations that have gained new insights and ways of working

comment.narrative:
10 Dutch experts with Mozambican feedback regarding training mode and insights about the Southern African region.
This can be measured by: Inclusion of Mozambican cases in the courses executed in the future by the Dutch training organization.

title.narrative: II.P.6. Number of scholarship holders that became members of the alumni association of their host university (of applied sciences)

comment.narrative: 11 ESCN alumni + 66 new alumni via the short course execution (considering 10 different participants per short course for 6 courses and 6 for 1 course)

title.narrative: II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods

comment.narrative: Means of verification: Link to the ISO of STC and the evaluation in line with the ISO accreditation to achieve a continues improvement of project executed according to the PDCA (Plan Do Check Act) cycle.

title.narrative: II.P.1. Number of MoUs or other types of formal collaboration agreements exist 1, 3, 5 years after end of project

comment.narrative: The new long-term cooperation agreement (November 2020) between ESCN and STC is valid for 10 years.
